Strongly agreeing with this request! We've had the same issue with my son's account. When he couldn't figure out where his Minecoins went, I discovered there's absolutely no way to track purchase history on the Nintendo Marketplace. The current system has two major flaws:

  1. The "sort by newest" feature doesn't even work properly (often showing older items before newer ones)
  2. There's no price information for past purchases, making it impossible to track Minecoin spending

A simple transaction log showing the item name, purchase date, and Minecoin cost would solve this completely. This seems like such a basic feature for any digital marketplace. Hope the team can implement this soon!

We had a similar situation in which I thought Minecoins didn't post to the account. I submitted a support ticket for missing Minecoins at https://help.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/request/new. For "What is the Category of Your Questions?" I selected "Marketplace Support" and for "What is the Subject for Your Question?" I selected "Cannot Find Purchase". After a few emails, I thought to ask for a transaction history. The helpful people in support were able to provide it. I would recommend others who are in the same situation to request this information from support as well until this feature is implemented. It is a pretty standard feature, so I don't think this is a crazy request. 

If this is for your children, the support ticket must be created with a parent's account. I would recommend noting the child's account information in the "What can we help with?" section so support can actually look into it. A support ticket created with a child's account under 12 years will apparently be closed immediately with a friendly note to have a parent resubmit the ticket.

I don‚Äôt see a proper base on the arguments against this. Mojang would never make our existing resources paid, as removing resourcepack, datapack, or map making support for free would also remove the people that would be making things for this new marketplace. What people tend to forget is that Microsoft has spent over 2.5 billion dollars on this game. They obviously need some way to make their money back. If they don‚Äôt this game is not making them profit and they‚Äôd have to stop development. Currently, java is a prime example of this. Our current options are that Java either gets a marketplace or development on it stops all together, and we all get to play the glitch fest that is bedrock edition. Those are just my first points, this is also an amazing idea because it allows datapack, resourcepack, and map development to actually be profitable for creators on java. For anyone wondering why I didn‚Äôt mention mods. Mods are a third party entity to Minecraft that run off things like forge or fabric. This would mean they wouldn‚Äôt be in this marketplace. I also highly doubt any skins would be either. In conclusion, Microsoft would be completely brain dead to not take advantage of this completely open opportunity to make not only more jobs for Minecraft content creators, but also some extra money.

Pros: Gives every console with access to minecraft the ability to download and install addons onto any world. Allows more creators to individually create content without the need of a team behind the map creation.

Cons: There is a limit to the free posts a marketplace creator can make. (To my knowledge it is 2 or 3 per account could have been changed though). Not every user has access to a source of income to purchase addons as well as creators don't always want to force a payment wall behind their work.

When posting a game onto steam it costs $100 per game whether it's free or not and people don't complain about that. It would also prevent people from spamming less quality filled addons since each one would cost them to post. First of all, congratulations to Bedrock Edition for finally having its own separate add-ons market.

However, I am concerned about the prospects of paid add-ons. It is well known that due to Mojang's own laziness and stinginess, the Bedrock Edition community has long been far less vibrant than the Java Edition. With players already able to see many high-quality mods available for the Java Edition, I doubt there will be much motivation left for them to pay. For Bedrock Edition to take money from players, it needs to offer add-ons of extremely high quality... But guess what? The interfaces Mojang has opened up are not even as good as those in MC China Edition. Add-ons there mostly consist of entities.

Bedrock Edition, as a stable version that can be played across multiple platforms, with Microsoft stepping in almost from scratch, should have been able to fix most of Java Edition's downsides and have a brilliant future. But now it's like a zombie, already dead but still moving.

Please open up more interfaces and encourage the community to create high-quality add-ons. The Bedrock Edition market could become a very promising money tree.

Also, get rid of that xxxx render dragon so players can create their own shader packs, or do it yourselves and release an official shader pack. Or buy each player an RTX 4090.

Even though we've said so much, will Mojang do it? Looking back over the past decade, I can pessimistically sentence all of this to death.

I sincerely hope I'm wrong.

We propose the addition of a centralized in-game system to manage and display guides for Marketplace and Add-on content, similar in functionality to Java Edition's popular FTB Quests or Just Enough Items mods. This system would eliminate the need for individual "Guide Books" to spawn in the player's inventory, improving user experience and world cleanliness.
Problem:
The current method for providing information on add-ons (through physical books that appear upon world load) leads to significant issues, including:
Clutter: Spawning multiple books when a player uses several add-ons, cluttering the inventory and game world.
Inconvenience: Players must locate and carry these books to access essential information.
Limited Functionality: The books are static and lack the interactive features of a true in-game guide
Proposed Solution:
Introduce a new, unified system accessible via the pause menu or a dedicated button in the player's inventory. This system would serve as a central hub for all add-on information, offering:
A Centralized Library: A digital "quest book" or "manual" that automatically populates with guides for all installed add-ons.
Interactive Features: Each entry could contain sections, searchable keywords, and potentially even track quests or progress related to the add-on's features.
Enhanced Player Experience: This would provide a cleaner, more intuitive way for players to learn about new content, reducing frustration and improving the overall quality of Addons

I think this is a great idea. Currently people that use custom skins do not get to enjoy the rewards for achievements without having to stop using their own custom skin, and for some players, this means to stop being themselves. The Character Creator should be a way for players to get to express themselves and put themselves in the game, but without custom skins, a lot of us do not get to truly put ourselves in the game. Sales should not be a problem with this feature being added, as I think it will actually increase them. There are many nice items like the Santa Hat or Top Hat that I would buy if I could put them on my custom skin, and many others probably would too. A way to implement this could be to add a custom skin button to the character creator or add it in the "base" section. When selected, all things (like mouth and top, all the stuff that would normally be selected to show some kind of skin) should be set to none. Players can then add things by selecting the parts they want to have on their skin and ignoring ones that would mess it up. The things they choose should overwrite any previous stuff in the position, such as adding eyes would change a specific part of the skin, even if it is not where the actual eyes are on the skin. There could be a button added to move parts like facial hair or eyes on the skin (within limits) to fix this. A hat should overwrite floating hair pixels to prevent errors happening with 3D parts. Please give us the ability to be ourselves!
